children.description: Medical eligibility. The DDSs, which are fully funded by the Federal Government, are State agencies responsible for developing medical evidence and making the initial determination on whether or not a claimant is disabled or blind under the law.

children.name: Retroactive Benefits
children.description: Social Security retroactive benefits are one-time payments that reimburse people for missed monthly payments. These payments can be due to application process delays or if someone applies for benefits after reaching full retirement age (FRA).

children.name: Wage/income verification
children.description: Financial eligibility. Submitting pay stubs and showing work hours and income level to prove if you are under the financial threshold.

children.name: Old Age and Survivors Insurance (OASI) (retirement benefits)
Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA)
children.description: A cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) is an increase made to Social Security benefits and Supplemental Security Income (SSI) to counteract the effects of inflation and rising prices in the economy.

children.name: Income Related Monthly Adjustment Amounts (IRMMA)
children.description: Higher Medicare premimuns assessed for increase in income (sale of home, payroll, etc)

children.name: Lump Sum Death Payment
children.description: A lump sum death payment of $255 is available from Social Security to the surviving spouse or eligible children of a deceased worker. To qualify, the surviving spouse must have been living with the deceased at the time of death or, if living apart, was receiving certain Social Security benefits on the deceased's record. If there's no eligible spouse, the payment can go to eligible children. The application must be filed within two years of the worker's death.

children.name: Medicare Enrollment
children.description: Medicare is the US health insurance program for people age 65 or older. Citizens sign up for Medicare Part A and Part B through Social Security, so you can make both retirement and Medicare choices and withhold any premiums from your benefit payments.

children.name: Representative Payee
children.description: If a constituent is entitled to a certain social security benefit and SSA says they need to get someone else to receive payment because the constituent is unfit for whatever reason, they are assigned a Representative Payee.  Social Security's Representative Payment Program provides benefit payment management for our beneficiaries who are incapable of managing their Social Security.

children.name: Retroactive Benefits
children.description: Social Security retroactive benefits are one-time payments that reimburse people for missed monthly payments. These payments can be due to application process delays or if someone applies for benefits after reaching full retirement age (FRA). Back pay is compensation that was due in a previous period of time but was not paid due to an employer's improper or wrongful actions.

children.name: Survivor Benefit
children.description: Survivor benefits provide monthly payments to eligible family members of people who worked and paid Social Security taxes before they died.

children.name: Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP)/Government Pension Offset (GPO)
children.description: Your Social Security benefit might be reduced if you get a pension from an employer who wasn’t required to withhold Social Security taxes. This reduction is called the “Windfall Elimination Provision” (WEP). It most commonly affects government work or work in other countries. Your benefit might be reduced if you get a pension from a government employer who wasn’t required to withhold Social Security taxes. This reduction is called the “Government Pension Offset” (GPO).

children.name: Whistleblowing
children.description: When an indivual discloses information regarding violations of laws, gross mismanagement, waste of funds, or dangers to public health and safety, thereby encouraging transparency and accountability within government agencies.

children.name: Billing/Payment Inquiry
children.description: Questions or concerns about medical billing or payment. Part B premium only goes through social security if not on an advantage plan-- payment might be withheld.

children.name: Eligibility
children.description: Questions or disputes about whether a constituent is eligible to receive Medicare.

children.name: Equitable relief
children.description: Equitable relief is a process that allows you to request the following from the Social Security Administration (SSA): Immediate or retroactive Medicare enrollment, or  Elimination of the Medicare Part B late enrollment penalty (LEP). To request equitable relief, you must have failed to enroll in Medicare due to the error, misrepresentation, or inaction of a federal employee, such as a Social Security or 1-800-MEDICARE representative. Equitable relief does not apply if you were misinformed about your Medicare rights and options by non-federal employees, such as an employer.

children.name: IRMAA
children.description: Income related monthly adjustment amount. If you make over a certain threshold, medicare will raise part B and D rate. This is the amount above the standard monthly premium you pay.

children.name: Late Enrollment Penalty (LEP)
children.description:
"It’s important to sign up for Medicare coverage during your Initial Enrollment Period, unless you have other coverage that’s similar in value to Medicare (like from an employer). If you don’t, you may have to pay an extra amount, called a late enrollment penalty. Generally, you won’t have to pay a Part B penalty if you qualify for a Special Enrollment Period. Learn more about Special Enrollment Periods.
You’ll pay an extra 10% for each year you could have signed up for Part B, but didn’t."

children.name: Medicare card replacement
children.description: Lost Medicare card and needs a new one.

children.name: Extra Help Program/LIS
children.description: The Extra Help program helps people with limited income and resources lower or cut Part D costs.

children.name: Administrative Law Judge
children.description: Second tier.  Under the Office of Hearings Operations (OHO), administrative law judges (ALJ) conduct hearings and issue decisions. Administrative Law Judges (ALJs) are federal employees who work for the Social Security Administration (SSA) to conduct hearings and issue decisions on benefits and regulations. They play a key role in determining whether Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) claims are approved or denied.

children.name: Appeals Council
children.description: Third tier. As the last administrative decisional level, the Appeals Council issues the Social Security Administration's (SSA) final action for claims filed under Title II and Title XVI of the Social Security Act. The Appeals Council was established to oversee the hearings and appeals process, promote national consistency in hearing decisions made by referees (now administrative law judges) and make sure that the Social Security Board's (now the Commissioner's) records were adequate for judicial review.  Within the Office of Analytics, Review, and Oversight (OARO), the Appeals Council considers appeals from hearing decisions and acts as the final level of administrative review for the agency.

children.name: Court of Appeals
children.description: Four tier. Very rare. Judicial branch court.

children.name: Overpayment
children.description: An overpayment occurs when Social Security pays you more than you should have been paid. If this happens, we will notify you. Our notice will tell you why you have been overpaid and how you can pay us back.

children.name: Request for Reconsideration
children.description: First tier appeal/ local appeal. Appeal is saying you disagree with SSA decision

children.name: Waiver request
children.description: Overpayment waiver. Often filed at the same time as request for reconsideration. "I can't pay while waiting for appeals decision, please hold collections entirely or come up with a payment plan"

children.name: Representative Payee
children.description: If a constituent is entitled to a certain social security benefit and SSA says they need to get someone else to receive payment because the constituent is unfit for whatever reason, they are assigned a Representative Payee.  Social Security's Representative Payment Program provides benefit payment management for our beneficiaries who are incapable of managing their Social Security.

children.name: Asset verification
children.description: Financial eligibility. You are only eligible for SSI if you have under a certain amount of assets. Showing value of trusts, your car, etc.

children.name: Continuing Disability Review (CDR)
children.description: Medical eligibility.  Continuing Disability Review (CDR) is when Social Security periodically reviews your medical impairment(s) to determine if you continue to have a disabling condition.  If we determine that you are no longer disabled or blind, your benefits will stop.

children.name: Disability Determination Service (DDS)
children.description: Medical eligibility. The DDSs, which are fully funded by the Federal Government, are State agencies responsible for developing medical evidence and making the initial determination on whether or not a claimant is disabled or blind under the law.

children.name: Mandatory waiting period
children.description: Financial eligibility. Generally, if your application for Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) is approved, you must wait five months before you can receive your first SSDI benefit payment. This means you would receive your first payment in the sixth full month after the date we find that your disability began.

children.name: Records Request
children.description: Often related to getting medical records in the disability process.

children.name: Retroactive Benefits
children.description: Social Security retroactive benefits are one-time payments that reimburse people for missed monthly payments. These payments can be due to application process delays or if someone applies for benefits after reaching full retirement age (FRA).

children.name: Wage/income verification
children.description: Financial eligibility. Submitting pay stubs and showing work hours and income level to prove if you are under the financial threshold.

children.name: Needs SSN
children.description: Was never issued a SSN and needs one.

children.name: Social Security card replacement
children.description: Lost SSN card and needs a new one.

children.name: SSN
children.description: A Social Security number (SSN) is a unique nine-digit identifier issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) to U.S. citizens, permanent residents, and eligible nonimmigrant workers.

children.name: SSN duplication
children.description: Multiple people issued the same SSN.

name: United States African Development Foundation
description: The United States African Development Foundation (USADF) is an independent U.S. government agency established to support African-led development. It provides seed capital and technical support to African grassroots organizations, entrepreneurs, and small and medium-sized enterprises to foster economic growth and create pathways to prosperity for marginalized populations and underserved communities.

name: United States Agency for International Development (USAID)
description: The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) is the primary U.S. government agency responsible for administering civilian foreign aid and development assistance. It works to advance U.S. foreign policy goals by partnering with countries to promote economic growth, reduce poverty, improve global health, and provide humanitarian assistance.

name: Department of Agriculture (USDA)
description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) is a federal agency focused on food, agriculture, natural resources, and related issues. It provides leadership, conducts risk assessments, and offers financial opportunities and disaster resources.

children.name: Pet health certificates
children.description: APHIS protects the health and value of American agriculture and natural resources. Casework includes issues related to the issuing of health certificates for pets, including service animals, when traveling internationally.

children.name: DPRS
children.description: NFC is a shared services organization for financial management and HR services for multiple government agencies – they support OPM insurance products including the DPRS (Direct Premium Remittance System) which is an enrollment, billing, and collection process for FEHB for federal employees.

children.name: Home loans, Rental Assistance, Rental Housing Programs
children.description: USDA's Rural Housing Service offers a variety of programs to build or improve housing and essential community facilities in rural areas. Casework includes home loan issues, such as if an inspector might have to approve property.

children.name: Rural development grants
children.description: USDA provides financial resources and support for rural communities, residents, and businesses. Casework relates to rural development grant issues, such as grants that were frozen.

children.name: Rural development loans
children.description: USDA provides financial resources and support for rural communities, residents, and businesses. Casework relates to issues with receiving loans.

children.name: Whistleblowing
children.description: When an indivual discloses information regarding violations of laws, gross mismanagement, waste of funds, or dangers to public health and safety, thereby encouraging transparency and accountability within government agencies.

name: United States Postal Service (USPS)
description: The United States Postal Service (USPS) provides nationwide mail and package delivery, ensures universal service at affordable rates, and supports commerce and communication across the country.

children.name: Whistleblowing
children.description: When an indivual discloses information regarding violations of laws, gross mismanagement, waste of funds, or dangers to public health and safety, thereby encouraging transparency and accountability within government agencies.

name: Department of Veterans Affairs (VA)
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is a U.S. federal executive department responsible for providing a wide range of benefits, services, and support to veterans of the U.S. armed forces and their families. It operates the largest integrated healthcare system in the United States and also administers various other benefits like disability compensation, education assistance, home loan guarantees, and burial benefits.

children.name: Board Appeals
children.description: Escalated after VBA appeals. If you are dissatisfied or disagree with a VA decision, you have the right to file an appeal with the Board of Veterans’ Appeals. The Board will review the evidence presented and issue a decision. A Board Appeal may be an option for you if you submit your request within 1 year of the decision on your initial claim, Supplemental Claim, or Higher-Level Review (the 1-year timeframe starts from the date on your decision letter).

children.name: Burial Allowance
children.description: Veterans burial allowances (sometimes called “Veterans death benefits”) are funds that help cover burial, funeral, and transportation costs.

children.name: Burial Eligibility
children.description: Veterans, service members, and some family members may be eligible for burial in a VA national cemetery, or for burial benefits for those buried in a private cemetary or at sea.

children.name: Burial Flags
children.description: The National Cemetary Administration provides a United States flag to drape on a casket (or coffin) or place with an urn in honor of the military service of a Veteran or Reservist.

children.name: Memorialization
children.description: Constituents can apply for benefits for a deceased Veteran, service member, or family member for government Headstones, Markers, Medallions, Plaques, and Urns. When you choose to get a plaque or urn for a Veteran, they will no longer be eligible for burial in a VA national cemetery.

children.name: Presidential Memorial Certificates
children.description: A Presidential Memorial Certificate (PMC) is an engraved paper certificate signed by the current president.

children.name: Schedule Burial in VA National Cemetery
children.description: Constituents can schedule a burial in a VA National Cemetary for a Veteran, spouse or dependent family member. Most difficult is Arlington National Cemetary.

children.name: Office of Acquisition, Logistics, and Construction (OALC)
Construction projects/contract billing
children.description: Most commonly issues with contractors not receiving pay.

children.name: Privacy Act Release Form (PARF)
children.description: Conflicting guidance on what is required on a PARF to start a case.

children.name: Tort claim status
children.description: A VA tort claim is a legal process where a veteran can seek compensation from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) for injuries or damages caused by the negligence or wrongful actions of a VA employee acting within the scope of their employment.

children.name: VSO accredidation
children.description: Local VSO has to be accredited through an application process, often delays in this process.

children.name: Security Clearance
children.description: A VA security clearance refers to the process the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) uses to determine if someone is eligible for access to classified national security information or sensitive VA facilities and information. This process involves background investigations and suitability determinations, similar to other federal agencies, but with a focus on ensuring the safety and integrity of VA services.

children.name: Whistleblowing
children.description: When an indivual discloses information regarding violations of laws, gross mismanagement, waste of funds, or dangers to public health and safety, thereby encouraging transparency and accountability within government agencies.

children.name: GI bill education benefits
children.description: Veterans can qualify for educational benefits/tuition based on their service in the military. To prove eligibility they need access to their military history and documentation to be able to show that they qualify. Veterans can also transfer their GI bill educational benefits to their spouse or dependent. To prove eligibility, they need access to their military history and documentation to prove that their service meets the requirements for the transfer. Dependent benefits (sending kid to school), tuition payments to colleges coming in late, disputes over which school the VA would send someone to (restrictions on how much VA will pay and for how long)/college selection and duration

children.name: VA-backed home loans
children.description: Veterans can have up to one VA Mortgage Loan at a time and need a certificate from VA to prove they are eligibile before going to a lender and applying for the VA loan.  Casework likely involves difficulties getting access to records (like DD214) to prove eligibility.

children.name: VET TEC
children.description: Veteran Employment Through Technology Education Courses (VET TEC) was a 5-year pilot program that matched Veterans with leading training providers to help them develop skills to start or advance their careers in high-tech industries.

children.name: Copy of service treatment records
children.description: Handles records and FOIA requests, including armed services treatment records.

children.name: Aid & Attendance
children.description: Service-disabled vet or spouse and you can't take care of yourself toward end of life, this is for nursing home fees

children.name: Agent Orange Claims
children.description: Agent Orange is a toxic herbicide and defoliant used by the U.S. military to clear foliage during the Vietnam War. Exposure to Agent Orange can cause a variety of health issues, including cancer, birth defects, and other life-threatening complications.

children.name: Camp Lejeune Claims
children.description: People —  including Veterans — previously exposed to contaminated water at Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, may file a new claim with the Department of the Navy. Individuals may seek relief in Federal court for a claim that is denied, or no decision is made six (6) months after a claim is filed.

children.name: Compensation & Pension
children.description: Service-related disability. VA assigns you a percentage for how much disabled, often this is an appeal to change this percentage, or VA reduced diability rating for you and you're disputing it, or VA mimsplaced documentation

children.name: Concurrent receipt
children.description: If you stay in the military long enough for retirement benefits and are also eligible for C&P, those interact in strange ways. People in military retirement and also receiving disability compensation at the same time --  CRDP Concurrent Retirement and Disability Pay.

children.name: Deployment benefits
children.description: Stopping and restarting benefits based on deployment.

children.name: Dependent benefits
children.description: Issues with all benefits for dependents -- your pay rate for compensation and pension go up when you have depedents and then down when they age out.

children.name: Death Indemnity Compensation
children.description: If you’re the surviving spouse, child, or parent of a service member who died in the line of duty, or the survivor of a Veteran who died from a service-related injury or illness, you may be able to get a tax-free monetary benefit called VA Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (VA DIC).

children.name: Delayed initial rating
children.description: When you apply for compensation and pension disability rating, your case goes into the national work queue.

children.name: Fiduciary
children.description: When VA says veteran isn't capable of handling own money, they are given a fidciary to handle money for them. disputed whether they need a fiduciary or trying to speed up process to get one assigned

children.name: Higher-Level Reviews
children.description: If you disagree with a VA decision, you or your representative can request a new review of your case by a higher-level reviewer. The reviewer will determine whether an error or a difference of opinion changes the decision. You can’t submit new evidence with a Higher-Level Review.

children.name: Legacy Appeals
children.description: Appeals for decisions dated before February 19, 2019. VA RAMP (Rapid Appeals Modernization Program) was a pilot program launched by the Department of Veterans Affairs in 2017 to modernize and streamline the appeals process for veterans' disability compensation claims. RAMP operated from November 2017 to February 2019, when it was replaced by the full implementation of the Appeals Modernization Act (AMA).

children.name: Not receiving pay
children.description: Issues with veterans not receiving pay.

children.name: Overpayment
children.description: disputing amount of overpayment or disputing that the overpayment option, or asking for a payment plan instead of fully docking from benefits .often related to compensation and pension, often related to dependents (ex. your daughter moved out 6 months ago but we are still paying her stipend, need that back)

children.name: PACT Act Claims
children.description: The PACT Act is a law that expands VA health care and benefits for Veterans exposed to burn pits, Agent Orange, and other toxic substances. This law helps us provide generations of Veterans—and their survivors—with care and benefits.

children.name: Presumptive conditions
children.description: Medical conditions where if you have them they corrolate with cetain disability percentages. Are my records robust enough to show I was somewhere where they were spraying agent orage, or records were destoryed and don't have proof

children.name: Survivor pension
children.description: VA survivor benefits provide financial support and other assistance to eligible family members of deceased veterans. These include Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC) which is a monthly benefit paid to eligible surviving spouses and dependent children, Survivors Pension which is a needs-based monthly benefit for low-income surviving spouses and children of wartime veterans, Survivors' and Dependents' Educational Assistance (DEA) which provides education and training opportunities to eligible dependents of veterans who are permanently and totally disabled or died due to a service-connected disability, the Fry Scholarship which offers Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to children and surviving spouses of servicemembers who died in the line of duty after September 10, 2001, Burial and memorial benefits to eligibile veterans and family members, and the Home Loan Guaranty which allows surviving spouses to be eligibile for VA home loan benefits

children.name: Discharge upgrade — VA benefits
children.description: Level of benefits depends on level of discharge (SIX TOTAL). Requests to dispute/change the discharge status of discharged military personnel or speeding up process after level changes and benefits don't catch up. The discharge upgrade itself goes through the military branch, Naval Board etc. (for one of those six options), but then you might have to contact the VA about your benefits if there is an issue afterward.

children.name: VA Benefit Debt
children.description: Benefit debt includes debt related to VA disability compensation, non-service-connected pension, or education benefits.

children.name: Life Insurance
children.description: Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance (SGLI) Group life insurance for service members; Family Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance (FSGLI) Allows service members to add coverage for their spouse and dependent children; Traumatic Injury Protection (TSGLI) Short-term financial support to help service members recover from a severe injury; Veterans' Group Life Insurance (VGLI) Group term life insurance for veterans after they've ended their service.

children.name: Appeals
children.description: any decision related to Veterans benefits, comp and pension, disability benefits

children.name: Veteran Readiness & Employment (VR&E)
children.description: Help rehabilitate disabled veterans and get them ready for willful employment, VA will deny specific colleges and certain advanced degrees, diputing this. You may receive Veteran Readiness and Employment (VR&E) (Formerly known as Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment) services to help with job training, education, employment accommodations, resume development, and job seeking skills coaching. Other services may be provided to assist Veterans and Service members in starting their own businesses or independent living services for those who are severely disabled and unable to work in traditional employment.

children.name: Auto Grants
children.description: The VA Auto Adaptive Equipment (AAE) benefit helps disabled veterans and active-duty service members purchase and modify vehicles to accommodate their service-connected disabilities. It consists of two parts: the Automobile Allowance, a one-time payment for a specially equipped vehicle, and the Adaptive Equipment Grant, which provides funds to install modifications like power steering, lifts, and hand controls.

children.name: Home Grants
children.description: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) offers two main types of grants to help disabled veterans adapt their homes: Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) and Special Housing Adaptation (SHA) grants. SAH grants are for veterans with severe service-connected disabilities, while SHA grants are for veterans with certain other service-connected disabilities. Both grants help veterans modify their homes to improve accessibility and independence

children.name: CHAMPVA
children.description: If you’re the spouse, surviving spouse, dependent child, or family caregiver of a Veteran or service member, you may qualify for health care benefits. In certain cases, you may also qualify for health care benefits due to a disability related to your Veteran’s service. CHAMPVA (Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Department of Veterans Affairs) provides health coverage to eligible dependents and survivors.

children.name: Community Care
children.description: Issues constituents are having with providers in the community. Includes speciality medical care not always provided by the VA, often referred to private sector.

children.name: Community providers
children.description: Providers in the community having trouble being paid by VA, or groups seeking permission to become a provider

children.name: Care Coverage
children.description: Determining or disputing whether the VA will cover a medical test or procedure that could be considered elective.

children.name: Disruptive behavior flags
children.description: Get flagged as making a scene at a VA hostpital and then unable to go to premises again without security. No appeal process

children.name: Foreign medical program (FMP)
children.description: Reiumbursement when vets get care overseas. Long delays in processing because often need translation.

children.name: Health Care Eligibility
children.description: In order to be eligible for VA benefits, a Veteran must have served 24 continuous months or the full term of their active duty. Exceptions are made for those discharged due to a disability incurred or aggravated in the line of duty, hardship, exposure to toxins or other hazards during service, and combat-zone veterans.

children.name: Homeless Veteran Care
children.description: VA conducts coordinated outreach to proactively seek out Veterans in need of assistance, connects homeless and at-risk Veterans with housing solutions, health care, community employment services and other required supports, and collaborates with federal, state and local agencies; employers; housing providers, faith-based and community nonprofits; and others to expand employment and affordable housing options for Veterans exiting homelessness.

children.name: Mental Health Services
children.description: The VA provides a comprehensive range of mental health services for veterans through the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA). Services include inpatient/outpatient care, crisis services, treatement for PTSD, Depression, Anxiety, Bipolar Disorder, Schizophrenia, and Substance abuse disorders, military sexual trauma (MST), suicide prevention, psychotherapy, counseling and more.

children.name: PTSD
children.description: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a mental health condition that's triggered by a terrifying event — either experiencing it or witnessing it. Symptoms may include flashbacks, nightmares and severe anxiety, as well as uncontrollable thoughts about the event.

children.name: Rural care
children.description: Medical care in rural areas, often referred to private sector.

children.name: VA Employee/Employment Issues
children.description: VA employee reaches out with a concern about their job, VA assistant general or special counsel, ex "my nursing license won't tranfer"

children.name: VA Travel Pay Reimbursement
children.description: VA travel pay reimbursement pays eligible Veterans and caregivers back for mileage and other travel expenses to and from approved health care appointments.

children.name: Experimental treatments
children.description: VA-sponsored clinical trials. Ex. ketamine clinics

children.name: Electronic health records
children.description: Access OR correction to electronic health records -- the VA is upgrading their health management system and there have been issues, so making a correction is common.

children.name: Emergency Room Visits
children.description: If you go to a non-VA facility for emergency care—even one that’s in our community care network—you must follow certain rules so that the VA can cover the cost of your care.

children.name: Hospice
children.description: Hospice Care is comfort care provided to Veterans and their families if the Veteran has a terminal condition, with less than 6 months to live, and is no longer seeking treatment other than palliative care. Hospice Care can be provided at home, in an outpatient clinic or in an inpatient setting.

children.name: My HealthEVet
children.description: My HealtheVet offers constituents tips and tools to help partner with their health care team on managing patient health. It is a web portal that provides self-service tools to refill prescriptions, track medical appointments, communiate with healthcare providers and view medical records, as well as resources to help make informed medical decisions.

children.name: Prescriptions
children.description: Wanting to change prescription that a doctor gave to something else, etc.

children.name: Transportation
children.description: Getting to and from medical appointments (VA has a bus), also mileage reiumbursements.

children.name: Urgent Care
children.description: If you’re an eligible Veteran, you can get urgent care at VA medical centers and in-network urgent care providers near you. Use urgent care for minor injuries and illnesses that aren’t life-threatening—like strep throat, sprained muscles, and skin and ear infections.

children.name: Long-term care
children.description: As a Veteran, you may be able to get assisted living, residential (live-in), or home health care through VA.

children.name: Vaccinations
children.description: Shortages and access to vaccines.

children.name: Caregiver Support Program
children.description: In-home care provided by VA, or familiy member who is part of caregiver program

children.name: CBOCs
children.description: Community based outpatient clinic

children.name: Vet centers
children.description: Small doctor office, not hospitals
